title: Acute Calculous Cholecystitis
diagnosis_topic: Inflammation of the gallbladder secondary to cystic duct obstruction
setup_script: A 45-year-old woman presents with right upper quadrant pain for the past 24 hours. She has fever and nausea. On exam there is a positive Murphy's sign.

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 130/85 mmHg, HR 100 bpm, RR 18/min, Temp 38.3 C.
WBC 14 K/uL, mildly elevated AST/ALT and bilirubin; amylase and lipase normal.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident orders right upper quadrant ultrasound
dynamic_flow.reply: Gallbladder wall thickening >4 mm, pericholecystic fluid and gallstones obstructing the cystic duct.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident initiates NPO status, IV fluids and analgesia
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient's pain improves slightly; keep NPO.
Ceftriaxone and metronidazole to cover Gram-negative and anaerobic organisms.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident consults surgery for early laparoscopic cholecystectomy
dynamic_flow.reply: Plan to operate within 24-72 hours of symptom onset.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays surgery beyond 1 week
dynamic_flow.reply: Risk of complications and conversion to open surgery increases.
Consider in critically ill patients unfit for surgery.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident notes repeated episodes of biliary colic
dynamic_flow.reply: Chronic cholecystitis can occur; early surgery prevents recurrence.
Obstruction leads to inflammation, infection and gallbladder wall thickening.
Early oral intake, pain control and discharge within 24 hours if uncomplicated.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident educates about risk factors
dynamic_flow.reply: Female sex, obesity, rapid weight loss, pregnancy and oral contraceptive use.

critical_decision_points: Diagnosis of acute cholecystitis via history, exam and ultrasound
Initiation of resuscitation, antibiotics and pain control
Indications and timing for early laparoscopic cholecystectomy
Consideration of percutaneous drainage in high-risk patients
Postoperative care and patient education on risk factors
